text: Precisamente, la combinación de construir en la zona marítimo-terrestre, algo que amenaza los recursos costeros como las dunas y corales que detienen el oleaje, y las consecuencias del cambio climático, que provoca huracanes y eventos de marejadas más fuertes y frecuentes, son la principal razón del problema, dice el científico.
translation1_googleTranslate: The main reason for the problem is the combination of building in the maritime-terrestrial zone, which threatens coastal resources such as dunes and corals that stop the waves, and the consequences of climate change, which causes stronger and more frequent hurricanes and storm surges, says the scientist.
translation2_chatGPT: Precisely, the combination of building in the maritime-terrestrial zone, something that threatens coastal resources such as dunes and corals that buffer the waves, and the consequences of climate change, which causes hurricanes and stronger and more frequent storm surge events, is the main reason for the problem, says the scientist.

text: "El cambio climático entra en juego en el proceso de erosión por el aumento en el nivel del mar, debido a que se están derritiendo los polos", dice, para explicar las razones por las que las marejadas que se "comen" la costa son cada vez más potentes.
translation1_googleTranslate: "Climate change is playing a role in the erosion process caused by rising sea levels, as the poles are melting," he says, explaining why the tidal waves that are "eating away" at the coast are becoming more and more powerful.
translation2_chatGPT: "Climate change comes into play in the erosion process due to the rising sea levels, because the poles are melting," he says, explaining the reasons why the storm surges that "eat away" the coast are becoming more powerful.

text: Un informe de la Agencia Nacional Oceánica y Atmosférica de EE.UU. de 2022 señala que, al menos en San Juan, la capital del territorio caribeño, se ha registrado desde 1962 un aumento de 1,77 centímetros en el nivel del mar por década (equivalente al índice de aumento del nivel global del mar).
translation1_googleTranslate: A 2022 report by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration notes that at least in San Juan, the capital of the Caribbean territory, there has been a rise of 1.77 centimeters in sea level per decade since 1962 (equivalent to the rate of global sea level rise).
translation2_chatGPT: A report from the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in 2022 notes that, at least in San Juan, the capital of the Caribbean territory, there has been an increase of 1.77 centimeters in sea level per decade since 1962 (equivalent to the global sea level rise rate).

text: Aunque parezca poco, el informe detalla que el efecto que ese cambio tiene en las marejadas es "preocupante", más aún cuando en la isla un 60% de la población vive en la costa.
translation1_googleTranslate: Although this may not seem like much, the report details that the effect of this change on storm surges is "worrying", even more so when 60% of the island's population lives on the coast.
translation2_chatGPT: Although it may seem small, the report details that the effect this change has on swells is "concerning," especially considering that 60% of the population on the island lives on the coast.

text: Y aunque el nivel del mar aumenta alrededor de todo el mundo, el impacto de la erosión es tan marcado en Puerto Rico porque su gobierno ha permitido una construcción desmedida en la costa, basando sus leyes, reglamentos y política pública en definiciones heredadas de una legislación del tiempo colonial español, critica el profesor Chaparro
translation1_googleTranslate: And although sea levels are rising around the world, the impact of erosion is so marked in Puerto Rico because its government has allowed excessive construction on the coast, basing its laws, regulations and public policy on definitions inherited from legislation from the Spanish colonial period, criticizes Professor Chaparro.
translation2_chatGPT: And although sea level is rising around the world, the impact of erosion is so pronounced in Puerto Rico because its government has allowed unchecked construction on the coast, basing its laws, regulations, and public policy on definitions inherited from legislation from the Spanish colonial era, criticizes Professor Chaparro.
